title-group.article-title: Commentary on "Tax by Design: The Mirrlees Review"

abstract.p: The objective of this commentary is to explore the relationship between the reforms proposed in Tax by Design and the recent academic literature. This literature provides solid support for the Mirrlees Review's dramatic proposals to eliminate any personal taxes on the normal rate of return to savings and to eliminate any net tax on new business investment. There is also solid support for the full taxation of any excess returns on financial investments, including income from capital gains. The commentary does raise questions, though, about the specific methods proposed to achieve these reforms. The proposal advocates adoption of rate-of-return allowances for individual savings under the personal tax and for business investment under the corporate tax. A commonly proposed alternative is to redefine the personal tax base to equal annual consumption and to allow expensing of new investment under the corporate tax. With such reforms to the personal tax, there is no longer even a clear reason to retain a corporate tax. The commentary also emphasises the pressures arising from cross-border investments and cross-border migration of individuals, issues given little attention in the review. These questions regard details of implementation. The overall proposals receive strong support in the academic literature.

To the extent that saving is discouraged, however, portfolio distortions are introduced. These distortions exist whenever securities with equal rates of return without taxes on savings no longer have equal rates of return with such taxes. Whenever the timing of payouts differs across securities - for example, capital gains income is deferred until realisation - the relative values of securities change as the discount rate changes, introducing such distortions.

This, for example, is the tax treatment of pension savings. The government bears a fraction of the initial costs equal to the tax rate and receives a fraction of the future return equal to the tax rate prevailing then. If the tax rate is constant over time, this sharing of costs and benefits of the investment with the government has no effect on the rate of return received by the investor.

If households can borrow and lend freely, then these changes in the timing of taxes are irrelevant. However, individuals cannot easily borrow against their future income, so are forced to save out of their low earnings while young in order to finance down payments on a house or car purchase, and expenses for child rearing. Easing these liquidity constraints through use of an expenditure tax can then provide an efficiency gain. Note, though, that if the household is a net borrower, so that income is below consumption, then liquidity constraints are more severe under an expenditure tax than under a tax using an RRA.

The Reagan administration made use of such fiscal illusion when introducing a Roth IRA as an alternative to a regular IRA (Individual Retirement Account). Compared with a regular IRA, contributions are not deductible under a Roth IRA, leading to an immediate revenue increase, but withdrawals are not taxable, leading to a future revenue loss. The budgetary window at that point was very short, making a shift from a regular IRA to a Roth IRA artificially look like a net revenue gain.
